**Daoist Scriptures on Dao/Way, Spirits, and Ghosts**

**Scripture Title:** *Dao/Way Requires Spirits and Ghosts* (Dao Yao Lingzhi Shengui Pin Jing)
*One scroll. Author unknown.*

**Source and Collated Versions:**
Extracted from the *Orthodox Daoist Canon* (Zhengtong Daozang) – Canonical Section (Zhengyibu).
Collated with the following Dunhuang manuscripts:
1. P. 2395,
2. S. 3370 (S. 3370 Zhao),
3. S. 986,
4. P. 2432,
5. P. 2753,
6. 3297,
7. P. 3356,
8. S. 1728.
*(Hereafter referred to as the Dunhuang versions.)*

**General Preface on Spirits and Ghosts**
The *Lingbao Infinite Salvation Scripture* (Lingbao Wuliang Duren Jing) states:
*"The Central Dipper Grand Marshal (Zhongdou Dakuai) oversees all spirits, records life and death for the Earth Deities (Dizhi), and attends to their departures and arrivals, extracting them from the five sufferings and eight hardships of the Earthly Gate."*

The *Tongzhen Shangqing Secret Book of the Dragon Scripture* (Tongzhen Shangqing Yinshu Longwen Jing) states:
*"The Most High Dao Lord (Taishang Daojun) and the Primordial Heavenly King (Yuan Shi Tianwang) return to the Palace of Great Existence (Dahou Gong), where they revel in the wondrous courtyards of refined elegance (Miaoting Yanyuan). There, they gather violet clouds, chant the Seven Treasures (Qibao), spread crimson radiance (Danxia), array the Mysterious Platform (Xuantai), and all the splendid hues blaze forth. The light shatters the empty void (Yuxu), illuminating all the heavens, while the fragrance pervades the ten directions. Their brilliance is resplendent and ineffable—words cannot fully describe it. Thus, they convene the spirits of the boundless Dao (Wujing Lingzhi), from the teeming multitudes down to the smallest creatures, all rejoicing in their presence."*

**Spirits and Ghostly Manifestations**
The *Tongshen Sanhuang Jing* (Scripture of the Three Sovereigns’ Hidden Mysteries) states:
*"The divine (Shenming) knows what has not yet arisen—this is called *spirit* (shen). Clear hearing and sharp sight—this is also called *spirit* (shen)."*

The *Taiping Jing* states:
*"Spirit (Shen) arises from the Dao/Way (Dao) and moves through it, not from virtue/power (De). Thus, those who practice the Dao/Way (Dao) attain divine clarity (shenming), while those who rely on virtue/power (De) align with ghostly counsel (shenmou). The distinction between Dao/Way and virtue/power is clear—spirit and humanity are internally interdependent, and this can be observed today."*

It further states:
*"The ancient sages, divine and holy true persons (Shensheng Zhenren), all guarded the Dao/Way (Dao). In times of purity and stillness (Qingjing), even the spirits of food would call out and converse with them, just as people today summon guests."*

It also states:
*"The spirits of Heaven and Earth, the four seasons, and the five phases (Wuxing) all directly govern human destinies (minglu). How can one not revere them and remember their kindness? If one does not seek goodness, one offends the Heavenly Spirits (Tianshen). The Heavenly Spirits will then disrupt the seasons—when warmth should come, cold arrives, and when cold should come, warmth intrudes."*

It further states:
*"Great spirits are like loyal ministers to a state, maintaining and assisting the public order—this is what makes them great. If great spirits harbor private selfishness, the Heavenly Sovereign (Tianjun) will perceive it and withdraw their support. Thus, they dare not neglect their duties. Small spirits, however, are unrestrained."*

It also states:
*"The vital essences (shen) of the four seasons are like winds and waters, shifting to align with human intentions—whether benevolent or malevolent. When humans are upright, the spirits are upright; when humans are depraved, the spirits are depraved. Thus, one must find the right person to establish matters. Without the right person, the Dao/Way is difficult to apply."*

*"Water naturally conforms to the shape of its vessel—whether square or round—its form is without fixed constancy. Likewise, the winds and vital essences (qi) follow human cultivation, shifting between good and evil without fixed rule. This is their clear admonition (mingjie). The spirits of Heaven and Earth, along with the winds and vital essences (qi), all follow human actions—this is their clear admonition."*

The *Laozi Observing the Body Scripture of the Great Purity* (Laozi Guan Shen Taqing Zhongjing) states:
*"The eight trigrams’ Heavenly Spirits descend upon humans, eternally guarding the Great Unity (Taiyi) as emissaries of the eight directions. They oversee the calculations of the eight seasonal nodes (Bajie), determining the auspicious and inauspicious fortunes of the world.*

*The Heavenly Spirit of Qian (乾神) is surnamed Zhongni (仲尼), with the title Fuxi (伏戏).*
*The Heavenly Spirit of Kan (坎神) is surnamed Dashangzi (大象子).*
*The Heavenly Spirit of Gen (艮神) is surnamed Fei Xianwang (非先王).*
*The Heavenly Spirit of Zhen (震神) is surnamed Xiao Zengzi (小曾子).*
*The Heavenly Spirit of Xun (巽神) is surnamed Dayouhou (大忧侯).*
*The Heavenly Spirit of Li (离神) is surnamed Wenchang (文昌).*
*The Heavenly Spirit of Kun (坤神) is surnamed Yangzhuo (扬擢), with the radiant title Ruyang (耀王) and the name Nüwa (女娲).*
*The Heavenly Spirit of Dui (兑神) is surnamed Yishi (一世).*
*If humans regularly observe and honor the eight seasonal nodes (Bajie), it brings auspiciousness (ji)."*

The *Taishang Nüqing Guilü* (Most High’s Regulations for the Green Ghostly Woman) states:
*"For the first ten days of Jiazi (甲子), the malevolent spirit (Xingshen) is surnamed Xuan (玄), named Yuchong (玉冲).*
*For the second ten days of Jiaxu (甲戌), the malevolent spirit is surnamed Heng (恒), named Peng (捧).*
*For the third ten days of Jashen (甲申), the malevolent spirit is surnamed Ji (既), named Guinyinying (闺音盈).*
*For the fourth ten days of Jimao (甲午), the malevolent spirit is surnamed Ben (本), named Man (满).*
*For the fifth ten days of Jacheng (甲辰), the malevolent spirit is surnamed Heng (恒), named Jianzi (坚子).*
*For the sixth ten days of Jiayin (甲寅), the malevolent spirit is surnamed Su (苏), named Zaoyinluo (造音落).*
*These six malevolent spirits of Jia (六甲凶神) oversee calamitous and rebellious affairs (Eni Sha Shi)."*

The *Taishang Bashu Zhenjing* (Most High’s Scripture of the Eight Substances) states:
*"The first precept is: Do not dare to disrespect Heaven, nor claim that Heaven lacks spirit (shen), or that Earth lacks ghosts (gui)."*

**On Demons (Mozheng Pin)**
The *Taishang Taixiao Langshu Jing* (Most High’s Scripture of the Azure Tower’s Hidden Mysteries) states:
*"The Azure Tower’s youth (Langshu Qingtong) said: Demons (Mo) have many kinds—there are Heavenly Demons (Tianmo), Earthly Demons (Dimo), and Ghostly Demons (Guimo)."*

*"The Six Heavenly Great Demon Kings (Liutian Damo Wang) are the greatest of all demonic sovereigns. In their past lives, they cultivated great virtue/power (De), and thus they attained these demonic ranks. They compare their virtue/power with the Emperor of Heaven (Dishesa) and jointly oversee affairs in Heaven, Earth, and humanity. They are subordinate officials of the Most High Jade Capital (Taishang Yujing), beneath the Heavenly Emperor (Tiandi). They control all else."*

*"When humans study the Dao/Way (Dao), they first undergo trials by lesser demons (Xiao Mo). Once the Dao/Way is perfected, the Great Demon Kings (Damo Wang) all descend to test them. After passing the great trials, they are then recommended to ascend and take their place on the Jade Capital Platform (Yujing Tai)."*

The *Shengxuan Jing* (Scripture of Ascending the Mysterious) states:
*"The Most High said: Among eight men and eleven women who first hear this scripture, if they do not believe in it and leave their seats in doubt, the Heavenly Demons (Tianmo) will mislead them with false teachings, disturbing their hearts."*

**On Warrior Spirits (Lishi Pin)**
The *Tongyuan Jing* (Scripture of the Hidden Abyss) states:
*"Guardian Warrior Spirits (Shu Tang Lishi) record the names of humans and submit them to the officials of judgment (Kaoguan). These officials examine the spirits of those marked for calamity (Sha Ren), causing their vital essences (qi) and life forces (li) to stagnate, their souls (hun) and spirits (po) to wander, and thus leading to their deaths. Throughout the world, there is a Warrior Spirit named Wuxuan (乌玄), commanding 490,000 men. They patrol the borders, and if there are three-cavity (San Dong) masters reciting scriptures (Zhuanjing), even a single guardian or two will protect them, preventing any harm."*

**On Void Spirits (Kongshen Pin)**
The *Shengxuan Jing* (Scripture of Ascending the Mysterious) states:
*"The Most High incantation reads: ‘From the Eastern Void (Dongji Xukong), the Heavenly Spirits (Tian Shen) and Earthly Deities (Dizhi), the dragons and ghosts down to the lowest extremes, all descend into the Western Void (Xiji Xukong).’"*

**On the Heavenly Spirits and Earthly Deities (Tian Shen Di Zhi)**
*"Heavenly Spirits and Earthly Deities, dragons and ghosts—listen truly to my command! This virtuous man, Dao Ling, now takes a solemn vow for the future, to become a great Master of the Dao, protecting all beings. You spirits should, from this day onward, take a solemn vow as well, leading your officials with earnest devotion to guard and protect him."*

---

**On the Community Deities (She Shen Pin)**
*The Laozi: Catalogue of Heaven, Earth, Ghosts, and Spirits* states:
*"The community deity of the capital is the Heavenly Right Minister. Left Yang, Right Yin, surnamed Huang, named Chong, originally from Jiangling in Yangzhou’s Jiujiang. His rank is *wan shi* (ten thousand bushels), and he oversees all famous mountains of the world, with all great deities of the communities serving under him. The community deity of Henan is the Heavenly Three Lights. Left Qing, Right Bai, surnamed Dai, named Gao, originally from Bohai in Ji Province. His rank is *wan shi*, overseeing the interplay of yin and yang, cursing and taking lives—thus, at the end of his term, the Heavenly Court seals him, and he supervises all blood-feeding ghosts and malevolent spirits across the land, great or small, none of whom dare disobey him.*

*The San Huang Jing* states:
*"The community deity of Yuzhou is surnamed Fan, named Li; of Yongzhou, surnamed Xiu, named Li; of Liangzhou, surnamed Huang, named Zong; of Kezhou, surnamed Zhang, named Yu; of Yangzhou, surnamed Zhou, named Hun; of Xuzhou, surnamed Han, named Ji; of Qingzhou, surnamed Yin, named Yu; of Yanzhou, surnamed Fei, named Ming; of Jizhou, surnamed Feng, named Qianji, and surnamed Dai, named Gao.*

*These nine communities correspond to the nine stars of Heaven and the nine palaces, overseeing the nine regions. Even common people can recall the names of the nine community deities—when one invokes them by name and asks of right or wrong, they reveal auspicious or inauspicious omens. They can reward the virtuous, punish the wicked, and save the people."*

---

**On Mountain Spirits (Shan Shen Pin)**
*The Lower Section of the Scripture of the Daoist Official’s Inquiry* states:
*"If one wishes to dwell in secluded mountain retreats, one must first receive the scriptures, practice with reverence, and perform good deeds to subdue the mountain spirits. Mountains, great or small, all have spirits. The greater the mountain, the greater its spirit; the smaller the mountain, the smaller its spirit. When the spirit is harmed, the person cannot stand either. If one does not understand the highest teachings and does not cultivate virtue or perform deeds, how can one long dwell in the mountains?"*

*The Laozi: Catalogue of Heaven, Earth, Ghosts, and Spirits* states:
*"The prison overseer of Taishan is surnamed Jun, named Hou.
The prison overseer of Yangshan is surnamed Zhu, named Zhao.
Yushan, the Heavenly Well, is surnamed Xia, named Ze, governing in the southern mountains of Kuaiji, known as Xie Gong. He has governed for five hundred years.
Yuan Shan Jun, the Heavenly Clerk, is surnamed Yuan, named Zhang, governing in the southern mountains of Yangxian in Haojun, with a rank of three thousand bushels. He has governed for seven hundred and twenty years.
Yue Shan Jun, the Heavenly Attendant, is surnamed Xu, named Song.
The Eastern Mountain deity of Yin County is surnamed Lü, named Cheng, originally from Guanghan, with a rank of six thousand bushels. When the governor of Shudao died, Heaven sealed him, allowing him to govern Yin County, having ruled for five hundred and ten years.
Zhang’an Mountain deity is surnamed Xu, named Sui, originally a commoner of the county, with no rank. He appeared in white robes, dying at seventy, and was appointed by the Heavenly Left General to govern, with his mountain named Xu. Gradually gaining merit, he received blood offerings and has ruled for seven hundred and seventy-two years.
The Huangshan deity of Dan County is surnamed Hao, named Nüdòng, known as the Earthly Limit Feeder, awaiting official blood offerings. He has ruled for seven hundred and twenty years.
The Shumountain deity of the East is surnamed Qian, named Jiju.
The Liushan deity of the South is surnamed Liu, named Bo.
The Jiutongshan deity of the West is surnamed Ji, named Qiyang.
Kunlun Mountain of the North is the Heavenly Center and the Earthly Mother. Its deity is surnamed Tang, named Dàqīng. The father-son mountain deities are surnamed Zhou, named Zhòngzhū.
The Dayi Mountain deity is surnamed Wu, named Yòuwén.
The Manche Mountain deity is surnamed Fu, named Yòusī.
The Shuai Gong Mountain deity is surnamed Huang, named Tàichū.
The Wan Gong Mountain deity is surnamed Huang, named Zhòngzēng.
The Fang Gong Mountain deity is surnamed Huang, name Yuántái.
The Qian Gong Mountain deity is surnamed Huang, named Yòulín.
The Yuehan Gong Mountain deity is surnamed Chen, named Jǐngyuán.
The Nipo Mountain deity is surnamed Chen, named Shàosī.
The Xise Mountain Matron is named Nǚshèng.
The Fan Mountain Matron is named Nǚé, originally named Tongting Mountain.
Lúkuāng Jun, located in the central path, is the spirit of the sacred and taboo. His name is Su, with the style Junxiao.
The Man Mountain deity is surnamed Lü, named Ji, with the style Shùzhēn. During his lifetime, he was a teacher, governing in the southern mountains of Lù County.
The Keshan deity is surnamed Feng, named Zǐyí. His uncle was originally from Nàna, now governing in the western part of the county."*

**On Water Spirits (Shui Shen Pin)**
*The Lower Section of the Scripture of the Daoist Official’s Inquiry* states:
*"All waters have spirits, and the eight seas have spirit kings residing therein. Rivers, lakes, and the Heze all have deities. Moreover, dragons govern their clear depths. The River Marshal and Water Officials each have palaces and temples, also ranking beneath the seven treasures and the halls of all the immortals."*

*The Laozi: Observing Heaven in the Taiqing Scripture* states:
*"The deity of the River Marshal is named Fengyi, known as the Agent of the Unbound."*

*The Laozi: Catalogue of Heaven, Earth, Ghosts, and Spirits* states:

River Shangong, with the style Dìngmíng.
River Yangong, with the style Dìnglíng.

River Marshal Hébo, with the style Duānzhòng, also named Chóngzhòng.
Taozhong Jun, with the style Liúxiàng.
Sìshuǐ Jun, with the style Bóxíng."*

**Língzhī Guǐpǐn** (灵祇鬼品):
*The Tai Shang Tai Zhen Ke Shang Jing* (太上太真科上经) states:
"All ghosts, regardless of refinement or coarseness, upon reaching the seventh generation, their good or evil deeds are resolved.
Good ghosts ascend to the **Guǐxiān Lù** (鬼仙录), while evil ghosts endure the trials of the **Knife Mountains, Sword Trees, and Fire Churns** (刀山剑树火擭之考).
When their bones and flesh are utterly consumed, they enter the **Mínglíng Dìyù** (溟泠地狱), where they suffer for ten thousand *kè* (劫) without rebirth."

*The Shòuxiān Dào Jing* (授仙道经) states:
"The Four Directions' Iron Encircled Mountains (铁围山), vast beyond the mountains themselves.
The **Tai Shang Lao Jun** (太上老君) out of compassion for life, established the Iron Encircled Mountains.
To isolate malevolent ghosts, preventing them from harming mortals."

*The Dàodé Jing* (道德经) states:
"With the **Dao/Way** (道) governing the world, its ghosts are not numinous.
If its ghosts are not numinous, the numinous ones will not harm mortals."

*The Dòngyuān Jing* (洞渊经) states:
"The **Dao/Way** (道) speaks of the time since **Fuxi** (伏羲), when armies were defeated, countless lives perished in vain by the sword, and the multitudes of the dead—some with **Língshī** (灵尸), their bones disjointed, heads separated from their bodies—cannot reunite.
Some have no heads, hands without arms, mouths without eyes, numbering in the thousands and millions, wandering and guarding themselves, leaning against mountains, resting by waters.
They converse with **Lǐ Zǐ'áo** (李子敖) in the clouds, roaming the shores of the seas, encompassing the **Shù** (束) of the four directions, riding the wind and steering sparrows, snatching humans' chickens and dogs, and forcing them to become malevolent spirits.
Thus, **Yāo** (妖) and **Méi** (魅) thrive, seeking human blood for sustenance.

It further states:
"Also, there is the **Dōulú Nuòguǐ** (都卢那鬼), three *zhàng* (丈) in height, with eyes and mouth askew, ears six *chǐ* (尺) long, and hands gripping iron rods.
They specialize in striking and killing evil humans in their paths, and there are also sixty-nine thousand ghosts, some becoming great **Wū** (乌).
Where these **Wū** (乌) pass, all fall ill, and the illness leads to death.

There are thirty-six thousand malevolent ghosts, named **Tian Chi** (天池), each accompanied by thirty thousand followers.
They roam the world, wrongfully killing the innocent.

In the year **Rénwǔ** (壬午), there are thirty-nine thousand **Chìguǐ** (赤鬼), named **Dàtóu** (大头), descending to kill mortals.

Ghosts of the mountains and forests are named **Jiāng Zǐdū** (江子都), leading two million nine hundred thousand ghosts.
They lurk to kill humans, assuming the guise of old men, entering households, and startling chickens and dogs.

Additionally, there are thirty-nine thousand **Chìjī Xiǎoguǐ** (赤积小鬼), who also enter households and take humans' livestock.

There are also the **Dàyùn Qīngguǐ** (大运青鬼), three *zhàng* (丈) in length, numbering four hundred ninety thousand.
They wield red rods, striking down the populace, but do not approach those who uphold the **Dharma** (法) with virtue.

It further states:
"There are the **Dàléi Guǐ** (大雷鬼), named **Jiǔchāng** (九昌), leading eight million lesser ghosts.
They hold red rods, entering the Central Realm (中国), and striking down evil mortals, inflicting thirty-six kinds of illnesses, which kill the wicked.

There are eighty million **Chìwěi Guǐ** (赤尾鬼), named **Duōhé** (多河), with one head and three tails, nine *chǐ* (尺) in length.
They hold water in both hands, causing mortals to suffer from chills and fever, and inflict ninety kinds of illnesses, which kill the wicked.

There are also the **Dàtóu Guǐ** (大头鬼), three *cùn* (寸) long, numbering in the thousands and millions.
They descend with **Chìniǎo** (赤鸟) numbering a hundred thousand, entering households and killing mortals.

There are thirty-six kinds of **Cǎoguǐ** (草鬼), which kill mortals.
When humans enter grasslands to gather vegetables, the white roots, stems, leaves, and branches of the grass may contain ghostly toxins.
The toxins are named **Shēngrú** (生如), with brothers numbering a hundred million.
Their **Qi** (气) can kill mortals, and when they strike, the illness enters the human body within ten days or a month, affecting all four limbs and hundred joints.
These are the **Huángchì Guǐ** (黄赤鬼), three *cùn* (寸) and seven *fēn* (分) in length.

Female ghosts of the mountains are named **Luó Wēng** (罗翁), with twenty million female attendants and officers.
These female ghosts also dwell at the edges of mountains, forests, and waters, lurking to kill mortals.

There is also a female ghost named **Shíjiāng** (石姜), whose appearance is most grotesque.
She is one *zhàng* (丈) in height, with a black face and eyes askew, her entire body red and yellow, and her body reeking with foulness.
Mortals who see her flee in terror, but **Daoists** (道士) who have cultivated boundless merit and are destined for transcendence, should respect the **Three Heavenly Saints** (三天圣人), and honor their teachers in three ways:
1. Teach them to receive the **scriptures** (经) and respect their teachers, without slandering others;
2. Teach them to nourish and support all **Daoists** (道士), without harboring jealousy;
3. Teach them not to consort with ordinary mortals.

If they do not follow these three precepts, the **Heavenly Beings** (天人) will censure them, and the ghosts will stir up malevolence, making the **Dao/Way** (仙道) difficult to establish.

It further states:
"There are eight million ghosts named **Wūtú Lúnnuò** (乌涂伦那), seven *zhàng* (丈) in length, numbering in the thousands and millions.
There are also great **Chìniǎo** (赤鸟), as large as chariot wheels, flying to devour mortals.
Those who uphold the **Three Caverns Scriptures** (三洞之经) and walk in the **Dao/Way** (道) will see these plagues die out.

There are also eighty-nine million **Chìmiàn Guǐ** (赤面鬼), named **Míngzhēn** (明真), each leading thirty-nine thousand lesser ghosts.
All hold red rods, striking down evil mortals.

There are also three million **Báitóu Guǐ** (白头鬼), named **Qiānlún** (千轮)."

The **Thousand-Headed Ghosts** (千输身) are three *zhàng* in length, with black faces and white heads, numbering in the tens of millions, and they bring down thirty-nine thousand kinds of diseases upon mortals.

There are also three thousand six hundred ghosts of various kinds that kill people.

There are thirty thousand **Harmful Ghosts** (害鬼), one hundred thousand **Stone Ghosts** (石鬼), twenty thousand **Wood Ghosts** (木鬼), three million six hundred thousand **Water Ghosts** (水鬼), six hundred thousand **Earth Ghosts** (土鬼), and one hundred sixty thousand **Insect Ghosts** (虫鬼)—all capable of killing mortals. These ghosts attach themselves to these elements to slay people: drowning in water, struck by stones in mountains, felled by trees, struck by the **Yin Qi of the Tiger** (寅气), buried in earth, or injured by insects in grass—all are unnatural deaths.

From this day forward, Daoists must exhort and transform the common folk, men and women alike, urging them all to follow the Dao. If they do not, the ghosts will drive them away, and they will daily fear the ghostly armies coming to punish them.

There are also eight thousand **Black-Eyed Ghosts** (黑目鬼), six *cùn* in length, riding birds as they fly, appearing in water or arriving with wind and rain to afflict mortals.

When people die, there are also thirty-nine thousand **Sand Ghosts** (沙鬼), three *cùn* long, red and white in color, multiplying in water to afflict mortals. There are also eight hundred thousand **Great Lǒu Ghosts** (大漯鬼), named **Great-Headed** (大头), with their leaders likewise named. Each leads thirty thousand ghostly bandits into the homes of evil people, causing fires that cannot be extinguished.

There are also great ghosts named **Bēngzhōu** (崩周). The **Ten-Directional Great Ghosts** (十方大鬼) are named **Jìzǐ** (季子), **Yāngxiōng** (央兄), and **Táojiāng** (桃姜). In years of the **Renwu** (壬午) cycle, they each lead twelve ten-thousands to China, killing evil mortals.

There are also eighty-nine thousand **Black-Faced Great Ghosts** (黑面大鬼), named **Red-Headed** (赤头), two *zhàng* and two *chǐ* in length. Forty-nine ten-thousands lead their groups, each falsely claiming to be an emperor’s spirit, terrifying households and gathering all unregistered ghosts—those questioned by the **Worldly Spirits** (世问魍魉), male and female calamities, **Tóuluōdīnglè** (头罗丁勒), **Nányáng Yègōng** (南阳叶公), **Shímǔ Dàzǐ** (石母大子), **Yúnzhōng Lǐzǐ** (云中李子), and the **Three Heavens’ Unrestrained Ghosts** (敖三天捺无着之鬼). Since the beginning of the **Huángtiān Yuán** (皇天元) era, beings have been reborn with cunning deceit, failing to believe in the Great Dao. The **Five Directions’ Retrograde Calamities** (五方逆煞) and pestilential qi have grown rampant. Tigers, wolves, and ten-thousands of beasts grow large with this qi, while insects, serpents, and spirits worsen daily. There are a thousand ghosts flying and wandering chaotically, unrestrained. The Great Dao does not govern, the Celestial Masters do not intervene, and chaos spreads across the land, relentlessly killing the common folk—billions perish. Later, when Daoist men and women are born in office and encounter my secret scriptures, knowing the names of these ghosts, they will all be preserved from calamity, and the ten-thousands of ghosts will not dare approach.

The ghosts of those who drowned in water are also summoned to the heavens for questioning and punishment, once a month.

Since ancient times, there have been thirty-six thousand ghosts.

Their palace is in the northwest corner of Tàishān, also belonging to Tàishān. These **four ghosts (右四鬼)**, govern the **timing of winds and rains**, causing harm when they arise. When travelers encounter great winds and rains on the road, they may call upon these four ghosts’ names, and the malevolent *qi* will not dare to strike.

At night, they harm chickens, dogs, and livestock. If one knows their names, the ghosts will **submit and remain inactive (伏住)**, not daring to harm. The household will then have **auspicious virtue (福德)**, and this ghost will protect it, preventing external calamities from entering.

The **Ghost of the Year *Shēn* (申)**, named **Hòumù Gāo** (后穆高).
These **two ghosts (右二鬼)** dwell at the **nose of the beam supports (屋下梁柱头鼻)** beneath a household’s roof. Whether in the morning or evening, they possess spiritual efficacy and obstruct people. If one knows their names, the ghosts will not harm.

The **Ghost of Refined Essence (令精华)**, named **Bǔzuò** (补坐).
These **two ghosts (右二鬼)** arise when a household contains **copper or gold coins** that harbor *qi*. These ghosts may transform into human form, unsettling the residence. If one calls upon them, it brings auspiciousness.

The **Ghosts of Bālìang (巴良), Shègū (赦姑), and Yīngé (殷各)**.
These **three ghosts (右三鬼)** dwell in the **four corners of a household’s walls**, where the household’s husband and wife act unrighteously and defy *yin-yang* harmony. They bear **white talismans (白直符)**, and the talismans bear white petitions. They **erase a person’s life register (除人生籍)**. If one knows their names, the ghosts will not dare to act.

The **Ghosts of Tiānzǎi (天载) and Mǐnyīn Míngxiàng (苠音旻向)** (pronounced *mǐnyīn míngxiàng*).
These **two ghosts (右二鬼)** serve as the **door guardians and gate officials (门伯户丞)**. By day, they bring divine blessings, but by dusk, they become malevolent spirits. If one knows their names and, at a fixed hour, calls them **three times at the door or gate**, claps their hands, turns their head backward, and covers their ears **twice**, these ghosts will cease and not dare to cause harm.

The **Ghosts of Fǔjīnmùhé (斧金木和) and Kǎijiācū (铠钾粗)**.
These **two ghosts (右二鬼)** arise when a household’s roof is shaded by trees or bamboo groves, where crows, white herons, or other birds nest, all harboring malevolent spirits. If one knows their names and calls them **three times**, the ghosts will recognize that humans cannot be harmed and will die within **seven or nine days**. If one calls them in the **evening**, the ghosts will submit and not harm.

These **three ghosts (右三鬼)** are the spirits that **torment those afflicted with epilepsy (癫痫)**. They wear **red garments and black caps**, seizing people’s souls. If one knows their names, the illness will immediately abate, and the ghosts will not dare to act.

These **two ghosts (右二鬼)** are the spirits of **women’s menstrual blood**, constantly consuming *yin-yang* vitality. On the day of a woman’s menstruation, if one calls upon their names in the evening, the ghosts will not dare to harm.

These **two ghosts (右此二鬼)**, measuring **three *cùn* and three *fēn*** in length, wear **black clothing**, and govern **childbirth**. When a woman is in labor, one must not fail to invoke these ghosts’ names—doing so ensures they will not harm.

*"Heavenly Sovereign of Clarity, distant and exalted, O divine spirit of *yin*! Do not return with your *Mǎgū* (马姑) to my residence! *"Shíwèizǐ (石未子), Shíwèizǐ! O *Tàiyī* (太一), you are my servant! What malevolent ghost dares to obstruct? Exit swiftly!"*

- The **Southern Ghost of Red *Qi* (南方赤气鬼)**, surnamed **Zhāng**, named **Yuánbó (元伯)**, leads ten thousand ghosts and brings **heat-poison diseases**.
- The **Western Ghost of White *Qi* (西方白气鬼)**, surnamed **Zhào**, named **Gōngmíng (公明)**, leads ten thousand ghosts and brings **congestive *qi* diseases**.
- The **Northern Ghost of Black *Qi* (北方黑气鬼)**, surnamed **Zhōng**, named **Shìjì (士季)**, leads ten thousand ghosts and brings **dysenteric diseases**.
- The **Central Ghost of Yellow *Qi* (中央黄气鬼)**, surnamed **Shǐ**, named **Wényè (文业)**, commands ten thousand ghosts and brings **malignant ulcerous diseases**.

These **five directional ghosts (右五方鬼)** govern these illnesses. If one **recites their surnames and names according to the affliction**, the illness will immediately abate, and all calamities will disperse.

---
**Ghosts of Auspicious Clarity (善爽鬼品):**
As the *Tàijí Zhēnrén Fēixiān Bǎojiàn Shàngjīng* (太极真人飞仙宝剑上经) states:
*"Those with the talent of *Xiāomiǎo* (萧邈) and the singular hopes of the masses, who cultivate the boundless *qi* yet do not seek noble status, will ultimately receive the records of the **Three Officials (三官)** and be inscribed as **Ghosts of Auspicious Clarity (善爽之鬼)**."*

As the *Tàishàng Tàizhēn Kējīng* (太上太真科经) states:
*"Those who study the Dao, receive the precepts, and uphold them—if they transgress, they must swiftly reform. Even if not entirely absolved, they may attain a **good death (善死)**. Having heard the true scriptures, they perform meritorious deeds among the ghosts, ascending to become **Ghostly Immortals (鬼仙)**, all called **Spiritual Beings (灵人)**, and through diligence, they wander among the **Three Purities (三清)**."*

---
**Ghosts of Suffering Souls (苦魂鬼品):**
As the *Míngzhēn Kējīng* (明真科经) states:
*"In the boundless world, men and women who, in life, acted wickedly, cursed the virtuous, invoked spirits and gods, and swore oaths to the Three Officials—upon death, they suffer as **malevolent ghosts (恶对)**, imprisoned as **spectral prisoners (魂鬼囚徒)**, dragged through the **Three Officials and Five Peaks (三官五岳)**. They are flogged **three times daily**, enduring torments beyond speech."*

As the *Tàishàng Tàizhēn Kējīng* (太上太真科经) states:
*"The wicked, who violate the precepts, upon death return to the **dark oblivion (混瞑)**, becoming **ghosts (鬼)**, and suffer under the **Yin Tribunals (阴司)**."*

**Ghosts of the Six Heavens (六天鬼品):**
*"It is also said: Among those who study the Dao/Way, if one commits a fault and does not repent, or repents yet repeats it, or acts wickedly without lasting virtue, and rebels against the teacher and the Dao/Way, or consorts with evil groups, or neglects all practice, or secretly harbors malevolent thoughts—if upon death they feel no remorse, these belong to the **Six Heavenly Ghosts (六天)**, lurking in darkness like spectral souls, with no escape from their suffering."*

**Ghosts of the Refined Spirits (精魅鬼品):**
*"The **Great Supreme Female Qing Ghost Statutes (太上女青鬼律)** declare:
The ghost of **mountain spirits (山精)**, one foot in length, is called **Zhuòròu (濯肉)**.
The ghost of **tree spirits (树精)** is called **Qún-Tiáo (群夭)** or **Shì (式)**.
The ghost of **stone spirits (石精)** is called **Jūn-Yú-Jīn (煾於巾切内子)**.
The ghost of **tiger spirits (虎精)** is called **Jiànzǐ (健子)**.
The ghost of **serpent spirits (蛇精)** is called **Cèyīn-Jìshí (侧音戚石圭)**.
The ghost of **hunting spirits (狩精)** is called **Xiāo-Wū (皛何乌切子)**.
The ghost of **monkey spirits (猴精)** is called **Mǎlì-Cèliàng (马痢侧亮切子)**.
The ghost of **fox spirits (狐精)** is called **Lián-Dàiwǔ (连音代午)**.
The ghost of **iron spirits (铁精)** is called **Yīduàn (医顿)**.
The ghost of **gold spirits (金精)** is called **Kùnduì (困兑)**.
The ghost of **wood spirits (木精)** is called **Yǐzhèn (倚震)**.
The ghost of **fire spirits (火精)** is called **Fùlí (附离)**.
The ghost of **water spirits (水精)** is called **Tuōkǎn (托坎)**.
The ghost of **earth spirits (土精)** is called **Chéngchuān (乘川)**.
The ghost of **qi spirits (气精)** is called **Jiǎoqián (矫乾)**.
The ghosts of **arcane spirits (魍魉精邪)** and **thousands of malevolent spirits (千妖万魅)**.
The ghosts of **inverted Dao/Way spirits turned by the Three Officials of Heaven, Earth, and Water (天地水三官转道逆魅)**.
The ghosts of **aged fox and hare spirits (狐狸老精)** who self-proclaim their names.
The ghosts of **malevolent spirits (魔邪)** that instill terror within households.
All these ghosts wander the world, seizing upon human decline, awaiting misfortune to inflict, and aiding in calamities and disasters. They slander and harm, altering form and appearance, following the **qi** to torment people. Those who study the Dao/Way, knowing this, may perform meritorious deeds and cultivate **virtue/power (德)**, informing the **Great Supreme (太上)**, and all such spirits shall be subdued. At the start of each year, their names are recorded in petitions, and they are sentenced to flee. The multitude of ghosts scatter in panic."*

**Ghosts of Trees and Woods (树木鬼品):**
*"The **Great Supreme Female Qing Ghost Statutes (太上女青鬼律)** declare:
The ghost of **dug-up trees (掘树)** is called **Liánbùzhì (连不智)**.
The ghost of **great trees (大树)** is called **Fāngyù (方域)**.
The ghost of **small woods (小木)** is called **Zhuǎnqí (转其)**.
The ghost of **transmitted wood (传木)** is called **Rǔyuǎn (汝远)**.
The ghost of **wooden gourds (木榴)** is called **Wūyùn (呜赈)**.
The ghost of **great mountains (大山)** is called **Gōngqiáng (弓强)**.
The ghost of **small mountains (小山)** is called **Héyóu (和邮)**.
The ghost of **mountain halls (山室)** is called **Qǐxiāo (启削)**.
The ghost of **mountain passes (山都)** is called **Tiānwáng (天王)**.
The ghost of **mountain covers (盖山)** is called **Zhùwǎng (柱往)**.
The ghost of **river spirits (河伯)** is called **Dá (达)**.
The ghost of **Nine Rivers (九江)** is called **Huó (活)**.
The ghost of **Three Rivers (三河)** is called **Jiàn (建)**.
The ghost of **Four Marshes (四渎)** is called **Hòu (候)**.
The ghost of **Earthly Spirits (地清土公)** is called **Yuán (元)**.
The ghost of **Red Earthly Spirits (地赤土公)** is called **Chì (赤)**.
The ghost of **Fragrant Earthly Spirits (芳元)** is called **Yán (元)**.
The ghost of **Yellow Earthly Spirits (地黄土公)** is called **Kè (克)**.
The ghost of **White Earthly Spirits (本地白土公)** is called **Shù (述)**.
The ghost of **Black Earthly Spirits (本地黑土公)** is called **Fàng (放)**.
These are the **Earthly Spirits (土鬼)** that command the people of the soil.
The **Hungry Ghosts (饿鬼)**—as the *Tàishàng Zhēn Kējīng* (太上真科经) states:
*'The text declares: In life, men and women are restless and foolish, like tiny insects. In their greed to consume, they compete for food. Upon death, they become **Hungry Ghosts (饿鬼)**, swallowing fire and eating charcoal, their corpses drifting as spectral apparitions, returning to their homes to seek sustenance.'*

**Ghosts of the Plague (瘟鬼品):**
*"The **Great Supreme Female Qing Ghost Statutes (太上女青鬼律)** declare:
The **Plague Ghost of the Eastern Quarter (东方青气瘟鬼)** is called **Gāoyuǎn (高远)**.
The **Plague Ghost of the Southern Quarter (南方赤气瘟鬼)** is called **Shìxuán (士玄)**.
The **Plague Ghost of the Western Quarter (西方白气瘟鬼)** is called **Bósāng (伯桑)**.
The **Plague Ghost of the Northern Quarter (北方黑气瘟鬼)** is called **Wénxiá (文遐)**.
The **Plague Ghost of the Central Quarter (中央黄气瘟鬼)** is called **Jūn (君)**.
The **Sixth Great Yellow Slave Plague Ghost (太黄奴第六鬼)** is called **Zhūnǚ (诛女)**;
The **Seventh Plague Ghost (第七鬼)** is called **Líng (陵)**.
The **Seven Plague Ghosts’ Ancestor (七鬼祖父)** is called **Liángzhōu (梁州)**,
Their **Ancestress (祖母)** is called **Jiāochéng (交成)**,
Their **Father (父)** is called **Yánnián (延年)**,
Their **Mother (母)** is called **Chūzhōng (出中)**.
These **five ghosts**, along with their **four ancestral spirits**, make up the **nine ancestral Plague Ghosts (九祖)**. Their parents retain human form yet can fly, spreading poison with the moon’s movement, to slay the wicked.
The **Plague Ghost of the First Month (正月瘟鬼)** is called **Wéi (惟)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Second Month (二月瘟鬼)** is called **Xīng (星)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Third Month (三月瘟鬼)** is called **Liú (刘)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Fourth Month (四月瘟鬼)** is called **Cún (存)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Fifth Month (五月瘟鬼)** is called **Cān-Qí (参音齐)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Sixth Month (六月瘟鬼)** is called **Yáng (徉)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Seventh Month (七月瘟鬼)** is called **Xìng (幸)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Eighth Month (八月瘟鬼)** is called **Huái (怀)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Ninth Month (九月瘟鬼)** is called **Chén (晨)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Tenth Month (十月瘟鬼)** is called **Bēi (卑)**.
The **Plague Ghost of the Eleventh Month (十一月瘟鬼)** is called **Yíng (赢)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Twelfth Month (十二月瘟鬼)** is called **Jiān (坚)**.
These **twelve monthly Plague Ghosts (十二月瘟鬼)** each unleash their respective calamities in their appointed months.
The **Plague Ghost of the Day of the Rat (子日瘟鬼)** is called **Gēn (根)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Day of the Ox (丑日瘟鬼)** is called **Dàng (荡)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Day of the Tiger (寅日瘟鬼)** is called **Yí (怡)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Day of the Rabbit (卯日瘟鬼)** is called **Yí (疑)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Day of the Dragon (辰日瘟鬼)** is called **È (厄)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Day of the Snake (巳日瘟鬼)** is called **Ài (爱)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Day of the Horse (午日瘟鬼)** is called **Wù (悟)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Day of the Goat (未日瘟鬼)** is called **Núzhǎng (奴长)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Day of the Monkey (申日瘟鬼)** is called **Mù (木)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Day of the Rooster (酉日瘟鬼)** is called **Shí (石)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Day of the Dog (戌日瘟鬼)** is called **Zhì (志)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Day of the Pig (亥日瘟鬼)** is called **Yōu (忧)**.
When these plague spirits descend, all people and diseases obey them.
**Liúyuándá (刘元达)** and others spread their poisonous harm across the Five Directions. Those who do not follow the Dao/Way or uphold its precepts are struck by their disasters. But those who practice goodness, purify themselves, preserve the Dao/Way, and follow its teachings—if they know the names of these ghosts—shall all subdue them.
Those who must depart shall be sent far away;
Those who must remain shall be driven back, their evil cohorts dispersed.
They shall then make new pacts, no longer harming the virtuous."*

**Ghosts of the Hex (蛊鬼品):**
*"The **Great Supreme Female Qing Ghost Statutes (太上女青鬼律)** declare:
The **First Hex Ghost (第一蛊鬼)** is called **Shìqú (释渠)**;
The **Second Hex Ghost (第二蛊鬼)** is called **Guǐgāo (鬼高)**;
The **Third Hex Ghost (第三蛊鬼)** is called **Lǐgāo (礼高)**;
The **Fourth Hex Ghost (第四蛊鬼)** is called **Chéngyàn (成晏)**;
The **Fifth Hex Ghost (第五蛊鬼)** is called **Bùxiáng (不祥)**;
The **Sixth Hex Ghost (第六蛊鬼)** is called **Wūwù (乌悟)**;
The **Seventh Hex Ghost (第七蛊鬼)** is called **Lǜzhī (绿支)**;
The **Eighth Hex Ghost (第八蛊鬼)** is called **Yùyí (育夷)**;
The **Ninth Hex Ghost (第九蛊鬼)** is called **Shíwǔ (石午)**.
These **Nine Hex Ghosts (九蛊)** engage in all manner of bewitchment, bewildering both **heavenly and human beings (天人)**. Together with the **Five Plague Ghosts (五瘟)** and **Great Yellow Slave (大黄奴)**, they spread their toxic **qi**.
The **Scriptures on the Dao/Way’s Essentials for Spirits and Ghosts (道要灵祇神鬼品经)** conclude."*

chunks.original_text: 道要灵祇神鬼品经 经名：道要灵祇神鬼品经。 一卷。 不着撰人。 底本出处：《正统道藏》正一部，参校版本：敦煌写本：一、P . 2395，二、S. 3370召，三、S. 986，四、P．2432，五、P．2753 六、3297，七、P . 3356 ，八、S. 1728 （简称敦煌本） 总序灵祇 《灵宝无量度人经》云：中斗大魁，总监众灵，劫制地祇，侍卫送迎，拔出地户五苦八难。 《洞真上清隐书龙文经》云：太上道君元始天王，同还大有之宫，游宴妙庭之绾，凝紫云，诵七宝，敷丹霞，列玄台，众华采灿，光烂玉虚，彻映诸天，香溢十方，焕烂朗馥，不可称宣，尔乃集会无极灵祇，爰及蠕动，莫不欢喜。 灵只神品 《洞神三皇经》云：神明者，豫知未萌，名曰神矣； 耳目聪明，名日神矣。 《太平经》云：夫神者，因道而行，不因德也。 故用道者与神明，用德者与神谋，道之与德更明思，神与人者内相恃，皆今可睹。 又云二古者，神圣真人皆能守道，清静之时，且食诸神皆呼而与其语言，比若今人呼客矣。 又云：天地四时五行，众神更直人命录，可不敬重，念报其恩。 不欲为善，事反天神。 天神使风雨不调，行气转易，当寒反温，当温反寒。 又云：大神比如国家忠臣，治辅公位，名为大神。 大神有小私，天君闻知，复退矣，故不敢懈怠。 小神者，安得自在。 又云：四时之精神，犹风也，水也，随人意而为邪正。 人正则正，人邪则邪，故须得其人乃可立事也。 不得其人，道难用也。 夫水本随器方圆，方圆无常，风气亦随人治为，善恶无常。 此即其明戒也。 天地之神与风气影响随人，为明戒耳。 《老子观身太清中经》云：八卦天神下着於人，常卫太一，为八方使者，主八节之日上计校定天下吉凶。 乾神，字仲尼，号伏戏。 坎神，字大象子。 艮神，字非先王。 震神，字小曾子。 巽神，字大忧侯。 离神，字文昌。 坤神，字扬擢，耀王号日女娲。 兑神，字一世。 人常以八节日存念之，吉。 《太上女青鬼律》云：甲子十日一旬，凶神姓玄，名玉冲，甲戌十日一旬，凶神姓恒，名捧。 甲申十日一旬，凶神姓既，名闺音盈。 甲午十日一旬，凶神姓本，名满。 甲辰十日一旬，凶神姓恒，名坚子。 甲寅十日一旬，凶神姓苏，名造音落。 右六甲凶神主恶逆煞事。 《太上八素真经》云：第一之戒，不得不敬於天，不得谓天无神，呼地无鬼。 魔正品 《太上太霄琅书经》云：束华青童曰：魔有数种：有天魔、地魔、鬼魔。 今古？ 六天大魔王者，是天地之大魔王，其宿世有大功德，故得为此魔王，与帝释比德共执事於天地人，上属太上玉京，为天帝之下官耳，其余无所不制。 夫人学道，先经小魔试，道成时大魔王皆临，大试过，便保举上登玉京台。 《升玄经》云：太上曰：有八男子、十一女人，初闻此经，生不信，意从座而退，为天魔异道惑乱其心。 力士品 《洞渊经》云：守堂力士录人名字，付考官，考官考煞人精神，令人气力啜怀，魂魄游扬，遂致死亡。 天下有力士名乌玄，四十九万人，游行国界，若有三洞法师转经之处，三五之人一二护之，不令有恶。 空神品 《升玄经》云：太上咒曰：东极虚空，天神地祇，龙鬼乃至，下极虚空。

**Daoist Scriptures on Dao/Way, Spirits, and Ghosts**

**Scripture Title:** *Dao/Way Requires Spirits and Ghosts* (Dao Yao Lingzhi Shengui Pin Jing)
*One scroll. Author unknown.*

**Source and Collated Versions:**
Extracted from the *Orthodox Daoist Canon* (Zhengtong Daozang) – Canonical Section (Zhengyibu).
Collated with the following Dunhuang manuscripts:
1. P. 2395,
2. S. 3370 (S. 3370 Zhao),
3. S. 986,
4. P. 2432,
5. P. 2753,
6. 3297,
7. P. 3356,
8. S. 1728.
*(Hereafter referred to as the Dunhuang versions.)*

**General Preface on Spirits and Ghosts**
The *Lingbao Infinite Salvation Scripture* (Lingbao Wuliang Duren Jing) states:
*"The Central Dipper Grand Marshal (Zhongdou Dakuai) oversees all spirits, records life and death for the Earth Deities (Dizhi), and attends to their departures and arrivals, extracting them from the five sufferings and eight hardships of the Earthly Gate."*

The *Tongzhen Shangqing Secret Book of the Dragon Scripture* (Tongzhen Shangqing Yinshu Longwen Jing) states:
*"The Most High Dao Lord (Taishang Daojun) and the Primordial Heavenly King (Yuan Shi Tianwang) return to the Palace of Great Existence (Dahou Gong), where they revel in the wondrous courtyards of refined elegance (Miaoting Yanyuan). There, they gather violet clouds, chant the Seven Treasures (Qibao), spread crimson radiance (Danxia), array the Mysterious Platform (Xuantai), and all the splendid hues blaze forth. The light shatters the empty void (Yuxu), illuminating all the heavens, while the fragrance pervades the ten directions. Their brilliance is resplendent and ineffable—words cannot fully describe it. Thus, they convene the spirits of the boundless Dao (Wujing Lingzhi), from the teeming multitudes down to the smallest creatures, all rejoicing in their presence."*

**Spirits and Ghostly Manifestations**
The *Tongshen Sanhuang Jing* (Scripture of the Three Sovereigns’ Hidden Mysteries) states:
*"The divine (Shenming) knows what has not yet arisen—this is called *spirit* (shen). Clear hearing and sharp sight—this is also called *spirit* (shen)."*

The *Taiping Jing* states:
*"Spirit (Shen) arises from the Dao/Way (Dao) and moves through it, not from virtue/power (De). Thus, those who practice the Dao/Way (Dao) attain divine clarity (shenming), while those who rely on virtue/power (De) align with ghostly counsel (shenmou). The distinction between Dao/Way and virtue/power is clear—spirit and humanity are internally interdependent, and this can be observed today."*

It further states:
*"The ancient sages, divine and holy true persons (Shensheng Zhenren), all guarded the Dao/Way (Dao). In times of purity and stillness (Qingjing), even the spirits of food would call out and converse with them, just as people today summon guests."*

It also states:
*"The spirits of Heaven and Earth, the four seasons, and the five phases (Wuxing) all directly govern human destinies (minglu). How can one not revere them and remember their kindness? If one does not seek goodness, one offends the Heavenly Spirits (Tianshen). The Heavenly Spirits will then disrupt the seasons—when warmth should come, cold arrives, and when cold should come, warmth intrudes."*

It further states:
*"Great spirits are like loyal ministers to a state, maintaining and assisting the public order—this is what makes them great. If great spirits harbor private selfishness, the Heavenly Sovereign (Tianjun) will perceive it and withdraw their support. Thus, they dare not neglect their duties. Small spirits, however, are unrestrained."*

It also states:
*"The vital essences (shen) of the four seasons are like winds and waters, shifting to align with human intentions—whether benevolent or malevolent. When humans are upright, the spirits are upright; when humans are depraved, the spirits are depraved. Thus, one must find the right person to establish matters. Without the right person, the Dao/Way is difficult to apply."*

*"Water naturally conforms to the shape of its vessel—whether square or round—its form is without fixed constancy. Likewise, the winds and vital essences (qi) follow human cultivation, shifting between good and evil without fixed rule. This is their clear admonition (mingjie). The spirits of Heaven and Earth, along with the winds and vital essences (qi), all follow human actions—this is their clear admonition."*

The *Laozi Observing the Body Scripture of the Great Purity* (Laozi Guan Shen Taqing Zhongjing) states:
*"The eight trigrams’ Heavenly Spirits descend upon humans, eternally guarding the Great Unity (Taiyi) as emissaries of the eight directions. They oversee the calculations of the eight seasonal nodes (Bajie), determining the auspicious and inauspicious fortunes of the world.*

*The Heavenly Spirit of Qian (乾神) is surnamed Zhongni (仲尼), with the title Fuxi (伏戏).*
*The Heavenly Spirit of Kan (坎神) is surnamed Dashangzi (大象子).*
*The Heavenly Spirit of Gen (艮神) is surnamed Fei Xianwang (非先王).*
*The Heavenly Spirit of Zhen (震神) is surnamed Xiao Zengzi (小曾子).*
*The Heavenly Spirit of Xun (巽神) is surnamed Dayouhou (大忧侯).*
*The Heavenly Spirit of Li (离神) is surnamed Wenchang (文昌).*
*The Heavenly Spirit of Kun (坤神) is surnamed Yangzhuo (扬擢), with the radiant title Ruyang (耀王) and the name Nüwa (女娲).*
*The Heavenly Spirit of Dui (兑神) is surnamed Yishi (一世).*
*If humans regularly observe and honor the eight seasonal nodes (Bajie), it brings auspiciousness (ji)."*

The *Taishang Nüqing Guilü* (Most High’s Regulations for the Green Ghostly Woman) states:
*"For the first ten days of Jiazi (甲子), the malevolent spirit (Xingshen) is surnamed Xuan (玄), named Yuchong (玉冲).*
*For the second ten days of Jiaxu (甲戌), the malevolent spirit is surnamed Heng (恒), named Peng (捧).*

Some have no heads, hands without arms, mouths without eyes, numbering in the thousands and millions, wandering and guarding themselves, leaning against mountains, resting by waters.
They converse with **Lǐ Zǐ'áo** (李子敖) in the clouds, roaming the shores of the seas, encompassing the **Shù** (束) of the four directions, riding the wind and steering sparrows, snatching humans' chickens and dogs, and forcing them to become malevolent spirits.
Thus, **Yāo** (妖) and **Méi** (魅) thrive, seeking human blood for sustenance.

It further states:
"Also, there is the **Dōulú Nuòguǐ** (都卢那鬼), three *zhàng* (丈) in height, with eyes and mouth askew, ears six *chǐ* (尺) long, and hands gripping iron rods.
They specialize in striking and killing evil humans in their paths, and there are also sixty-nine thousand ghosts, some becoming great **Wū** (乌).
Where these **Wū** (乌) pass, all fall ill, and the illness leads to death.

There are thirty-six thousand malevolent ghosts, named **Tian Chi** (天池), each accompanied by thirty thousand followers.
They roam the world, wrongfully killing the innocent.

In the year **Rénwǔ** (壬午), there are thirty-nine thousand **Chìguǐ** (赤鬼), named **Dàtóu** (大头), descending to kill mortals.

Ghosts of the mountains and forests are named **Jiāng Zǐdū** (江子都), leading two million nine hundred thousand ghosts.
They lurk to kill humans, assuming the guise of old men, entering households, and startling chickens and dogs.

Additionally, there are thirty-nine thousand **Chìjī Xiǎoguǐ** (赤积小鬼), who also enter households and take humans' livestock.

There are also the **Dàyùn Qīngguǐ** (大运青鬼), three *zhàng* (丈) in length, numbering four hundred ninety thousand.
They wield red rods, striking down the populace, but do not approach those who uphold the **Dharma** (法) with virtue.

It further states:
"There are the **Dàléi Guǐ** (大雷鬼), named **Jiǔchāng** (九昌), leading eight million lesser ghosts.
They hold red rods, entering the Central Realm (中国), and striking down evil mortals, inflicting thirty-six kinds of illnesses, which kill the wicked.

There are eighty million **Chìwěi Guǐ** (赤尾鬼), named **Duōhé** (多河), with one head and three tails, nine *chǐ* (尺) in length.
They hold water in both hands, causing mortals to suffer from chills and fever, and inflict ninety kinds of illnesses, which kill the wicked.

There are also the **Dàtóu Guǐ** (大头鬼), three *cùn* (寸) long, numbering in the thousands and millions.
They descend with **Chìniǎo** (赤鸟) numbering a hundred thousand, entering households and killing mortals.

There are thirty-six kinds of **Cǎoguǐ** (草鬼), which kill mortals.
When humans enter grasslands to gather vegetables, the white roots, stems, leaves, and branches of the grass may contain ghostly toxins.
The toxins are named **Shēngrú** (生如), with brothers numbering a hundred million.
Their **Qi** (气) can kill mortals, and when they strike, the illness enters the human body within ten days or a month, affecting all four limbs and hundred joints.
These are the **Huángchì Guǐ** (黄赤鬼), three *cùn* (寸) and seven *fēn* (分) in length.

Female ghosts of the mountains are named **Luó Wēng** (罗翁), with twenty million female attendants and officers.
These female ghosts also dwell at the edges of mountains, forests, and waters, lurking to kill mortals.

There is also a female ghost named **Shíjiāng** (石姜), whose appearance is most grotesque.
She is one *zhàng* (丈) in height, with a black face and eyes askew, her entire body red and yellow, and her body reeking with foulness.
Mortals who see her flee in terror, but **Daoists** (道士) who have cultivated boundless merit and are destined for transcendence, should respect the **Three Heavenly Saints** (三天圣人), and honor their teachers in three ways:
1. Teach them to receive the **scriptures** (经) and respect their teachers, without slandering others;
2. Teach them to nourish and support all **Daoists** (道士), without harboring jealousy;
3. Teach them not to consort with ordinary mortals.

If they do not follow these three precepts, the **Heavenly Beings** (天人) will censure them, and the ghosts will stir up malevolence, making the **Dao/Way** (仙道) difficult to establish.

It further states:
"There are eight million ghosts named **Wūtú Lúnnuò** (乌涂伦那), seven *zhàng* (丈) in length, numbering in the thousands and millions.
There are also great **Chìniǎo** (赤鸟), as large as chariot wheels, flying to devour mortals.
Those who uphold the **Three Caverns Scriptures** (三洞之经) and walk in the **Dao/Way** (道) will see these plagues die out.

There are also eighty-nine million **Chìmiàn Guǐ** (赤面鬼), named **Míngzhēn** (明真), each leading thirty-nine thousand lesser ghosts.
All hold red rods, striking down evil mortals.

There are also three million **Báitóu Guǐ** (白头鬼), named **Qiānlún** (千轮)."

chunks.original_text: 千输身长三丈，面黑头白，万万为群，当下三万九千种病。 又有三千六十鬼，种种煞人。 有害鬼三万，石鬼十万，木鬼二万，水鬼三千六十万，土鬼六十万，虫鬼十六万，悉能煞人也。 所以能煞人者鬼，悉附以此物之上，煞人。 入水死，入山石死，斩树木死，食寅气死，起土土死，入草虫伤，悉非正气也。 道士自今以去，劝化万姓，愚人男女，令悉奉道之人，鬼不近。 不者，大驱除之，日恐鬼兵来诛，子耳又有八千黑目鬼，鬼长六寸，托鸟而飞，来在水中，或因风雨来着人。 人死复有三万九千沙鬼，鬼长三寸，其色赤白，因水长便着人，复有八十万大漯鬼，鬼名大头，其主亦尔如，各领三万鬼贼入恶人宅中，令失火，火不可救。 复有大鬼，鬼名崩周。 十方大鬼，鬼名季子、央兄、桃姜，壬午之年各领十二万来中国，煞恶人。 又有八万九千黑面大鬼，鬼名赤头，身长二丈二尺。 四十九万人导群，每诈称皇帝之神，恐人家亲将一切无籍之鬼、世问魍魉男女之殃、头罗丁勒，南阳叶公、石母大子、云中李子，敖三天捺无着之鬼，千兆亿来入人宅，取人小口、老妪、男子，令天下人疾病死亡，村村有之，门门皆死，鬼兵屯聚，集人邻陌，捉人六畜、乌兽，作其光怪，令人遭口舌、刑徒囚狱，田蚕不收，触事凶凶。 《太上女青鬼律》云：自后皇天元年以来，转生百巧，不信大道，五方逆煞，疫气渐兴，虎狼万兽，受气长大，百虫蛇魅，与日而甚，日有千鬼，飞走乱行，不可禁止，大道不制，天师不劫，放纵天下，凶凶相逐，唯煞中民，死者千亿，后有道士男女生官，见吾秘经，知鬼姓名，皆保元吉，万鬼不干，高天万丈，大鬼百鬼，中皇姓模名天，是六万鬼之主，住在太山东南角。 水中诸死人所皈鬼，亦上天对问考罚，月一上。 上古以来，有三万六千鬼。 又南乡三老鬼，五道鬼，鬼姓车，名适，主诸死人录籍，考计生人罪恶，皆属之此鬼。 在太山西北角，亦有宫，属太山，有召一还，此鬼是天煞唯关文书。 东斗三台鬼，姓角，名车。 南斗三台鬼，姓殡武殿，名温夫。 西斗三台鬼，姓车，名球音求。 北斗三台招摇大鬼，姓伴，名玩。 中斗三台鬼，姓王，名咸。 右五斗煞鬼姓名主煞人。 大云中无名鬼，长三万六千丈。 天云中游行鬼，名扰音忧僖音熙子。 天云中二十八宿直煞鬼，名成子。 右三鬼天阴阳鬼主煞人。 东方青帝直符鬼，名伯神子，一名杲古老切子。 南方赤帝直符鬼，名泰伯子。 西方白帝直符鬼，名伯和子。 北方黑帝直符鬼，名泰衣子。 中央黄帝直符鬼，名伯溪子，一名泰渊。 右五方直符鬼，常煞人六畜，生作光怪。 北斗主煞一鬼，上下乌衣，长七千丈，姓昊名还临。 子太一主煞，无刑无名鬼长一丈六尺，赤绩赤衣，服天三五考煞鬼，名慧於戒切，长丈七尺，白衣赤积，天帝常司过鬼，姓阪音反名斑。 子夜听人语，逆知人心。 甲子日，鬼名元光。 乙丑日，鬼名邮音丙郭音章。 丙寅日，鬼名剧音昭昌。 丁卯日，鬼名子方。 戊辰日，鬼名生进。 己巳日，鬼名傅直专切令扶变切。 庚午日，鬼名柴方。 辛未日，鬼名音五故切文。 壬申日，鬼名石松。 癸酉日，鬼名倚晷音执。 甲戌日，鬼名甲光。

The **Thousand-Headed Ghosts** (千输身) are three *zhàng* in length, with black faces and white heads, numbering in the tens of millions, and they bring down thirty-nine thousand kinds of diseases upon mortals.

There are also three thousand six hundred ghosts of various kinds that kill people.

There are thirty thousand **Harmful Ghosts** (害鬼), one hundred thousand **Stone Ghosts** (石鬼), twenty thousand **Wood Ghosts** (木鬼), three million six hundred thousand **Water Ghosts** (水鬼), six hundred thousand **Earth Ghosts** (土鬼), and one hundred sixty thousand **Insect Ghosts** (虫鬼)—all capable of killing mortals. These ghosts attach themselves to these elements to slay people: drowning in water, struck by stones in mountains, felled by trees, struck by the **Yin Qi of the Tiger** (寅气), buried in earth, or injured by insects in grass—all are unnatural deaths.

From this day forward, Daoists must exhort and transform the common folk, men and women alike, urging them all to follow the Dao. If they do not, the ghosts will drive them away, and they will daily fear the ghostly armies coming to punish them.

There are also eight thousand **Black-Eyed Ghosts** (黑目鬼), six *cùn* in length, riding birds as they fly, appearing in water or arriving with wind and rain to afflict mortals.

When people die, there are also thirty-nine thousand **Sand Ghosts** (沙鬼), three *cùn* long, red and white in color, multiplying in water to afflict mortals. There are also eight hundred thousand **Great Lǒu Ghosts** (大漯鬼), named **Great-Headed** (大头), with their leaders likewise named. Each leads thirty thousand ghostly bandits into the homes of evil people, causing fires that cannot be extinguished.

There are also great ghosts named **Bēngzhōu** (崩周). The **Ten-Directional Great Ghosts** (十方大鬼) are named **Jìzǐ** (季子), **Yāngxiōng** (央兄), and **Táojiāng** (桃姜). In years of the **Renwu** (壬午) cycle, they each lead twelve ten-thousands to China, killing evil mortals.

There are also eighty-nine thousand **Black-Faced Great Ghosts** (黑面大鬼), named **Red-Headed** (赤头), two *zhàng* and two *chǐ* in length. Forty-nine ten-thousands lead their groups, each falsely claiming to be an emperor’s spirit, terrifying households and gathering all unregistered ghosts—those questioned by the **Worldly Spirits** (世问魍魉), male and female calamities, **Tóuluōdīnglè** (头罗丁勒), **Nányáng Yègōng** (南阳叶公), **Shímǔ Dàzǐ** (石母大子), **Yúnzhōng Lǐzǐ** (云中李子), and the **Three Heavens’ Unrestrained Ghosts** (敖三天捺无着之鬼). A thousand ten-thousands and billions gather in human dwellings, taking young children, old women, and men, causing illness and death across the land—villages are ravaged, households perish, ghostly armies assemble in alleys, seizing people and livestock, creating eerie phenomena, leading to slander, imprisonment, and failed harvests. All matters turn ominous.

The *Tàishàng Nǚ Qīng Guǐ Lǜ* (太上女青鬼律) states:
Since the beginning of the **Huángtiān Yuán** (皇天元) era, beings have been reborn with cunning deceit, failing to believe in the Great Dao. The **Five Directions’ Retrograde Calamities** (五方逆煞) and pestilential qi have grown rampant. Tigers, wolves, and ten-thousands of beasts grow large with this qi, while insects, serpents, and spirits worsen daily. There are a thousand ghosts flying and wandering chaotically, unrestrained. The Great Dao does not govern, the Celestial Masters do not intervene, and chaos spreads across the land, relentlessly killing the common folk—billions perish. Later, when Daoist men and women are born in office and encounter my secret scriptures, knowing the names of these ghosts, they will all be preserved from calamity, and the ten-thousands of ghosts will not dare approach.

In the **Highest Heaven** (高天), spanning ten-thousands of *zhàng*, the **Great Ghosts** (大鬼) and **Hundred Ghosts** (百鬼) are led by **Middle Sovereign** (中皇), surnamed **Mó**, named **Tiān**—the lord of the six ten-thousands of ghosts, residing at the southeast corner of **Tàishān** (太山). The ghosts of those who drowned in water are also summoned to the heavens for questioning and punishment, once a month.

Since ancient times, there have been thirty-six thousand ghosts.

There are also the **Three Elders of the Southern Region** (南乡三老鬼), the **Five Path Ghosts** (五道鬼), surnamed **Chē**, named **Shì** (适), overseeing the registries of the dead, calculating the sins of the living—all under their jurisdiction. Their palace is in the northwest corner of Tàishān, also belonging to Tàishān. There is a **Summon-and-Return** (召一还) ritual here, and this ghost is the **Heavenly Calamity** (天煞) responsible for official documents.

The **Three Stars of the Eastern Dipper** (东斗三台鬼) are surnamed **Jué** (角), named **Chē** (车).
The **Three Stars of the Southern Dipper** (南斗三台鬼) are surnamed **Bìn Wǔdiàn** (殡武殿), named **Wēnfū** (温夫).
The **Three Stars of the Western Dipper** (西斗三台鬼) are surnamed **Chē**, named **Qiúyīnqiú** (球音求).
The **Three Stars of the Northern Dipper’s Schaking Ghosts** (北斗三台招摇大鬼) are surnamed **Bàn** (伴), named **Wán** (玩).
The **Three Stars of the Central Dipper** (中斗三台鬼) are surnamed **Wáng**, named **Xián** (咸).

These five **Dipper Calamity Ghosts** (五斗煞鬼) by name govern the killing of mortals.

The **Nameless Ghost of the Great Clouds** (大云中无名鬼) is thirty-six thousand *zhàng* long.
The **Ghost Wandering the Heavenly Clouds** (天云中游行鬼) is named **Rǎoyīn Yōuxīyīn Xīzǐ** (扰音忧僖音熙子).
The **Twenty-Eight Constellations’ Directing Calamity Ghosts** (天云中二十八宿直煞鬼) are named **Chéngzǐ** (成子).

These three are the **Heavenly Yin-Yang Ghosts** (天阴阳鬼) who govern the killing of mortals.

The **Ghost of the Green Emperor’s Direct Symbol** (东方青帝直符鬼) is named **Bóshénzǐ** (伯神子), also called **Gǎogǔlǎoqièzǐ** (杲古老切子).
The **Ghost of the Red Emperor’s Direct Symbol** (南方赤帝直符鬼) is named **Tàibózǐ** (泰伯子).
The **Ghost of the White Emperor’s Direct Symbol** (西方白帝直符鬼) is named **Bóhézǐ** (伯和子).
The **Ghost of the Black Emperor’s Direct Symbol** (北方黑帝直符鬼) is named **Tàiyīzǐ** (泰衣子).
The **Ghost of the Yellow Emperor’s Direct Symbol** (中央黄帝直符鬼) is named **Bóxīzǐ** (伯溪子), also called **Tàiyuān** (泰渊).

These five **Directional Direct-Symbol Ghosts** (五方直符鬼) constantly kill mortals and livestock, manifesting as eerie phenomena.

The **Ghost Governing the Northern Dipper’s Calamity** (北斗主煞一鬼) wears black robes, is seven thousand *zhàng* long, surnamed **Hào**, named **Huánlín** (还临).

The **Ghost of the Child of the Great One** (子太一主煞) is a nameless, formless ghost one *zhàng* and six *chǐ* long, clad in red robes and red garments, serving as the **Heavenly Three-Five Punishment Ghost** (天三五考煞鬼), named **Huìyújiè** (慧於戒切), seven *zhàng* long, in white robes with red trim. The **Heavenly Emperor’s Ghost of Overseeing Offenses** (天帝常司过鬼) is surnamed **Bǎn** (阪, pronounced *fǎn*), named **Bān** (斑), listening to human speech at night and foreknowing their thoughts.

On **Jiazi** days, the ghost is named **Yuánguāng** (元光).
On **Yǐchǒu** days, the ghost is named **Yóu** (邮, pronounced *bó*) **Guō** (郭, pronounced *zhāng*) (邮音丙郭音章).
On **Bǐngyín** days, the ghost is named **Jù** (剧, pronounced *zhāo*) **Chāng** (昌) (剧音昭昌).
On **Dīngmǎo** days, the ghost is named **Zǐfāng** (子方).
On **Wùchén** days, the ghost is named **Shēngjìn** (生进).
On **Jǐsì** days, the ghost is named **Fù** (傅, pronounced *fú*) **Zhuān** (专, pronounced *biàn*) (傅直专切令扶变切).
On **Gēngwǔ** days, the ghost is named **Cháifāng** (柴方).
On **Xīnwèi** days, the ghost is named **Wén** (文, pronounced *wúgù*) (音五故切文).
On **Rénshēn** days, the ghost is named **Shísōng** (石松).
On **Guǐyǒu** days, the ghost is named **Yǐguǐ** (倚晷, pronounced *zhí*).
On **Jiǎxū** days, the ghost is named **Jiǎguāng** (甲光).

The **Ghost of Auspiciousness and Calamity (吉凶鬼)**, named **Jǐn** (谨).
The **Worldly Inverted Ghost (世逆鬼)**, named **Zhòngzǐ Luàn** (孨子脔, pronounced *luàn*).
These **two ghosts (右二鬼)** are the spirits of ancient deceased individuals who ruined households or unrighteous teachers of the common folk. They harm people in a hundred ways, but if one knows their names, the ghosts will **submit and remain inactive (伏住)**, daring not to move.

The **Heavenly Rectifying Ghost (天正鬼)**, named **Diédàjié** (迭大结, pronounced *jié*).
The **Earthly Rectifying Ghost (地正鬼)**, named **Zhuànglì Qínshuǐ** (枔立, pronounced *qín*; 水).
These **two ghosts (右二鬼)** are the **spirits guarding the dead energy (死煞)** within a residence, constantly dwelling in the rafters of a household’s halls. At night, they harm chickens, dogs, and livestock. If one knows their names, the ghosts will **submit and remain inactive (伏住)**, not daring to harm. The household will then have **auspicious virtue (福德)**, and this ghost will protect it, preventing external calamities from entering.

The **Ghost of the Year *Shēn* (申)**, named **Hòumù Gāo** (后穆高).
These **two ghosts (右二鬼)** dwell at the **nose of the beam supports (屋下梁柱头鼻)** beneath a household’s roof. Whether in the morning or evening, they possess spiritual efficacy and obstruct people. If one knows their names, the ghosts will not harm.

The **Ghost of Refined Essence (令精华)**, named **Bǔzuò** (补坐).
These **two ghosts (右二鬼)** arise when a household contains **copper or gold coins** that harbor *qi*. These ghosts may transform into human form, unsettling the residence. If one calls upon them, it brings auspiciousness.

The **Ghosts of Bālìang (巴良), Shègū (赦姑), and Yīngé (殷各)**.
These **three ghosts (右三鬼)** dwell in the **four corners of a household’s walls**, where the household’s husband and wife act unrighteously and defy *yin-yang* harmony. They bear **white talismans (白直符)**, and the talismans bear white petitions. They **erase a person’s life register (除人生籍)**. If one knows their names, the ghosts will not dare to act.

The **Ghosts of Tiānzǎi (天载) and Mǐnyīn Míngxiàng (苠音旻向)** (pronounced *mǐnyīn míngxiàng*).
These **two ghosts (右二鬼)** serve as the **door guardians and gate officials (门伯户丞)**. By day, they bring divine blessings, but by dusk, they become malevolent spirits. If one knows their names and, at a fixed hour, calls them **three times at the door or gate**, claps their hands, turns their head backward, and covers their ears **twice**, these ghosts will cease and not dare to cause harm.

The **Ghosts of Fǔjīnmùhé (斧金木和) and Kǎijiācū (铠钾粗)**.
These **two ghosts (右二鬼)** arise when a household’s roof is shaded by trees or bamboo groves, where crows, white herons, or other birds nest, all harboring malevolent spirits. If one knows their names and calls them **three times**, the ghosts will recognize that humans cannot be harmed and will die within **seven or nine days**. If one calls them in the **evening**, the ghosts will submit and not harm.

The **Ghosts of Chénfà (尘发), Tàiyú (汰音大), and Gòu (垢音娠)** (pronounced *tài yú*), **Ruòwú (若无)**, **Zhǐxǐ (紫吁)**, and **Fāngqǔ (方遘)** (pronounced *qǔ*).
These **three ghosts (右三鬼)** are the spirits that **torment those afflicted with epilepsy (癫痫)**. They wear **red garments and black caps**, seizing people’s souls. If one knows their names, the illness will immediately abate, and the ghosts will not dare to act.

The **Ghosts of Chénghuázài (乘华载) and Pìqìtúfù (辟气途付)**.
These **two ghosts (右二鬼)** are the spirits of **women’s menstrual blood**, constantly consuming *yin-yang* vitality. On the day of a woman’s menstruation, if one calls upon their names in the evening, the ghosts will not dare to harm.

These **two ghosts (右此二鬼)**, measuring **three *cùn* and three *fēn*** in length, wear **black clothing**, and govern **childbirth**. When a woman is in labor, one must not fail to invoke these ghosts’ names—doing so ensures they will not harm.

This **one ghost (右此一鬼)**, named **Dǐngjīnghuá (鼎精华)**, harms **silkworms and mulberry fields**, as well as **ghostly husbands of silkworm maidens**. On the **first day of *Lìchūn* (立春)**, at dawn, one may face the **northwest** and recite three incantations:
*"Heavenly Sovereign of Clarity, distant and exalted, O divine spirit of *yin*! Do not return with your *Mǎgū* (马姑) to my residence! May my silkworms multiply a thousandfold, my fields yield a hundred billion *hú* of grain, silk descend from the heavens, and rice rise from the earth! With mighty force, I command you—urgently crush all injuries, scatter small malevolent spirits like wolves! Chǐxiāo (适进), *bǎixiāo* (百逍)!"*

The **Ghosts of *Dànxī* (旦夕) Sweeping and Cleansing (扫除鬼)** cause people to lose wealth. If one knows their names, one may, on a **monthly day facing northwest**, call them **three times** and recite:
*"Shíwèizǐ (石未子), Shíwèizǐ! O *Tàiyī* (太一), you are my servant! What malevolent ghost dares to obstruct? Exit swiftly!"*

The **Five Directional Ghosts of *Qi* (气)**:
- The **Eastern Ghost of Green *Qi* (东方青气鬼)**, surnamed **Liú**, named **Yuándá (元达)**, leads ten thousand ghosts and brings **evil diseases**.
- The **Southern Ghost of Red *Qi* (南方赤气鬼)**, surnamed **Zhāng**, named **Yuánbó (元伯)**, leads ten thousand ghosts and brings **heat-poison diseases**.
- The **Western Ghost of White *Qi* (西方白气鬼)**, surnamed **Zhào**, named **Gōngmíng (公明)**, leads ten thousand ghosts and brings **congestive *qi* diseases**.
- The **Northern Ghost of Black *Qi* (北方黑气鬼)**, surnamed **Zhōng**, named **Shìjì (士季)**, leads ten thousand ghosts and brings **dysenteric diseases**.
- The **Central Ghost of Yellow *Qi* (中央黄气鬼)**, surnamed **Shǐ**, named **Wényè (文业)**, commands ten thousand ghosts and brings **malignant ulcerous diseases**.

These **five directional ghosts (右五方鬼)** govern these illnesses. If one **recites their surnames and names according to the affliction**, the illness will immediately abate, and all calamities will disperse.

---
**Ghosts of Auspicious Clarity (善爽鬼品):**
As the *Tàijí Zhēnrén Fēixiān Bǎojiàn Shàngjīng* (太极真人飞仙宝剑上经) states:
*"Those with the talent of *Xiāomiǎo* (萧邈) and the singular hopes of the masses, who cultivate the boundless *qi* yet do not seek noble status, will ultimately receive the records of the **Three Officials (三官)** and be inscribed as **Ghosts of Auspicious Clarity (善爽之鬼)**."*

As the *Tàishàng Tàizhēn Kējīng* (太上太真科经) states:
*"Those who study the Dao, receive the precepts, and uphold them—if they transgress, they must swiftly reform. Even if not entirely absolved, they may attain a **good death (善死)**. Having heard the true scriptures, they perform meritorious deeds among the ghosts, ascending to become **Ghostly Immortals (鬼仙)**, all called **Spiritual Beings (灵人)**, and through diligence, they wander among the **Three Purities (三清)**."*

---
**Ghosts of Suffering Souls (苦魂鬼品):**
As the *Míngzhēn Kējīng* (明真科经) states:
*"In the boundless world, men and women who, in life, acted wickedly, cursed the virtuous, invoked spirits and gods, and swore oaths to the Three Officials—upon death, they suffer as **malevolent ghosts (恶对)**, imprisoned as **spectral prisoners (魂鬼囚徒)**, dragged through the **Three Officials and Five Peaks (三官五岳)**. They are flogged **three times daily**, enduring torments beyond speech."*

As the *Tàishàng Tàizhēn Kējīng* (太上太真科经) states:
*"The wicked, who violate the precepts, upon death return to the **dark oblivion (混瞑)**, becoming **ghosts (鬼)**, and suffer under the **Yin Tribunals (阴司)**."*

**Ghosts of the Six Heavens (六天鬼品):**
*"It is also said: Among those who study the Dao/Way, if one commits a fault and does not repent, or repents yet repeats it, or acts wickedly without lasting virtue, and rebels against the teacher and the Dao/Way, or consorts with evil groups, or neglects all practice, or secretly harbors malevolent thoughts—if upon death they feel no remorse, these belong to the **Six Heavenly Ghosts (六天)**, lurking in darkness like spectral souls, with no escape from their suffering."*

**Ghosts of the Refined Spirits (精魅鬼品):**
*"The **Great Supreme Female Qing Ghost Statutes (太上女青鬼律)** declare:
The ghost of **mountain spirits (山精)**, one foot in length, is called **Zhuòròu (濯肉)**.
The ghost of **tree spirits (树精)** is called **Qún-Tiáo (群夭)** or **Shì (式)**.
The ghost of **stone spirits (石精)** is called **Jūn-Yú-Jīn (煾於巾切内子)**.
The ghost of **tiger spirits (虎精)** is called **Jiànzǐ (健子)**.
The ghost of **serpent spirits (蛇精)** is called **Cèyīn-Jìshí (侧音戚石圭)**.
The ghost of **hunting spirits (狩精)** is called **Xiāo-Wū (皛何乌切子)**.
The ghost of **monkey spirits (猴精)** is called **Mǎlì-Cèliàng (马痢侧亮切子)**.
The ghost of **fox spirits (狐精)** is called **Lián-Dàiwǔ (连音代午)**.
The ghost of **iron spirits (铁精)** is called **Yīduàn (医顿)**.
The ghost of **gold spirits (金精)** is called **Kùnduì (困兑)**.
The ghost of **wood spirits (木精)** is called **Yǐzhèn (倚震)**.
The ghost of **fire spirits (火精)** is called **Fùlí (附离)**.
The ghost of **water spirits (水精)** is called **Tuōkǎn (托坎)**.
The ghost of **earth spirits (土精)** is called **Chéngchuān (乘川)**.
The ghost of **qi spirits (气精)** is called **Jiǎoqián (矫乾)**.
The ghosts of **arcane spirits (魍魉精邪)** and **thousands of malevolent spirits (千妖万魅)**.
The ghosts of **inverted Dao/Way spirits turned by the Three Officials of Heaven, Earth, and Water (天地水三官转道逆魅)**.
The ghosts of **aged fox and hare spirits (狐狸老精)** who self-proclaim their names.
The ghosts of **malevolent spirits (魔邪)** that instill terror within households.
All these ghosts wander the world, seizing upon human decline, awaiting misfortune to inflict, and aiding in calamities and disasters. They slander and harm, altering form and appearance, following the **qi** to torment people. Those who study the Dao/Way, knowing this, may perform meritorious deeds and cultivate **virtue/power (德)**, informing the **Great Supreme (太上)**, and all such spirits shall be subdued. At the start of each year, their names are recorded in petitions, and they are sentenced to flee. The multitude of ghosts scatter in panic."*

**Ghosts of Trees and Woods (树木鬼品):**

The ghost of **great trees (大树)** is called **Fāngyù (方域)**.
The ghost of **small woods (小木)** is called **Zhuǎnqí (转其)**.
The ghost of **transmitted wood (传木)** is called **Rǔyuǎn (汝远)**.

The ghost of **great mountains (大山)** is called **Gōngqiáng (弓强)**.
The ghost of **small mountains (小山)** is called **Héyóu (和邮)**.
The ghost of **mountain halls (山室)** is called **Qǐxiāo (启削)**.
The ghost of **mountain passes (山都)** is called **Tiānwáng (天王)**.
The ghost of **mountain covers (盖山)** is called **Zhùwǎng (柱往)**.
The ghost of **river spirits (河伯)** is called **Dá (达)**.
The ghost of **Nine Rivers (九江)** is called **Huó (活)**.
The ghost of **Three Rivers (三河)** is called **Jiàn (建)**.
The ghost of **Four Marshes (四渎)** is called **Hòu (候)**.
The ghost of **Earthly Spirits (地清土公)** is called **Yuán (元)**.
The ghost of **Red Earthly Spirits (地赤土公)** is called **Chì (赤)**.
The ghost of **Fragrant Earthly Spirits (芳元)** is called **Yán (元)**.
The ghost of **Yellow Earthly Spirits (地黄土公)** is called **Kè (克)**.
The ghost of **White Earthly Spirits (本地白土公)** is called **Shù (述)**.
The ghost of **Black Earthly Spirits (本地黑土公)** is called **Fàng (放)**.

The **Hungry Ghosts (饿鬼)**—as the *Tàishàng Zhēn Kējīng* (太上真科经) states:

Upon death, they become **Hungry Ghosts (饿鬼)**, swallowing fire and eating charcoal, their corpses drifting as spectral apparitions, returning to their homes to seek sustenance.'*

The **Seventh Plague Ghost (第七鬼)** is called **Líng (陵)**.

Their **Father (父)** is called **Yánnián (延年)**,
Their **Mother (母)** is called **Chūzhōng (出中)**.

The **Plague Ghost of the Second Month (二月瘟鬼)** is called **Xīng (星)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Third Month (三月瘟鬼)** is called **Liú (刘)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Fourth Month (四月瘟鬼)** is called **Cún (存)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Fifth Month (五月瘟鬼)** is called **Cān-Qí (参音齐)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Sixth Month (六月瘟鬼)** is called **Yáng (徉)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Seventh Month (七月瘟鬼)** is called **Xìng (幸)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Eighth Month (八月瘟鬼)** is called **Huái (怀)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Ninth Month (九月瘟鬼)** is called **Chén (晨)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Tenth Month (十月瘟鬼)** is called **Bēi (卑)**.
The **Plague Ghost of the Eleventh Month (十一月瘟鬼)** is called **Yíng (赢)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Twelfth Month (十二月瘟鬼)** is called **Jiān (坚)**.

The **Plague Ghost of the Day of the Ox (丑日瘟鬼)** is called **Dàng (荡)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Day of the Tiger (寅日瘟鬼)** is called **Yí (怡)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Day of the Rabbit (卯日瘟鬼)** is called **Yí (疑)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Day of the Dragon (辰日瘟鬼)** is called **È (厄)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Day of the Snake (巳日瘟鬼)** is called **Ài (爱)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Day of the Horse (午日瘟鬼)** is called **Wù (悟)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Day of the Goat (未日瘟鬼)** is called **Núzhǎng (奴长)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Day of the Monkey (申日瘟鬼)** is called **Mù (木)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Day of the Rooster (酉日瘟鬼)** is called **Shí (石)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Day of the Dog (戌日瘟鬼)** is called **Zhì (志)**;
The **Plague Ghost of the Day of the Pig (亥日瘟鬼)** is called **Yōu (忧)**.
When these plague spirits descend, all people and diseases obey them.
**Liúyuándá (刘元达)** and others spread their poisonous harm across the Five Directions. Those who do not follow the Dao/Way or uphold its precepts are struck by their disasters. But those who practice goodness, purify themselves, preserve the Dao/Way, and follow its teachings—if they know the names of these ghosts—shall all subdue them.
Those who must depart shall be sent far away;
Those who must remain shall be driven back, their evil cohorts dispersed.
They shall then make new pacts, no longer harming the virtuous."*

**Ghosts of the Hex (蛊鬼品):**
*"The **Great Supreme Female Qing Ghost Statutes (太上女青鬼律)** declare:
The **First Hex Ghost (第一蛊鬼)** is called **Shìqú (释渠)**;
The **Second Hex Ghost (第二蛊鬼)** is called **Guǐgāo (鬼高)**;
The **Third Hex Ghost (第三蛊鬼)** is called **Lǐgāo (礼高)**;
The **Fourth Hex Ghost (第四蛊鬼)** is called **Chéngyàn (成晏)**;
The **Fifth Hex Ghost (第五蛊鬼)** is called **Bùxiáng (不祥)**;
The **Sixth Hex Ghost (第六蛊鬼)** is called **Wūwù (乌悟)**;
The **Seventh Hex Ghost (第七蛊鬼)** is called **Lǜzhī (绿支)**;
The **Eighth Hex Ghost (第八蛊鬼)** is called **Yùyí (育夷)**;
The **Ninth Hex Ghost (第九蛊鬼)** is called **Shíwǔ (石午)**.
These **Nine Hex Ghosts (九蛊)** engage in all manner of bewitchment, bewildering both **heavenly and human beings (天人)**. Together with the **Five Plague Ghosts (五瘟)** and **Great Yellow Slave (大黄奴)**, they spread their toxic **qi**.
The **Scriptures on the Dao/Way’s Essentials for Spirits and Ghosts (道要灵祇神鬼品经)** conclude."*
